comments.commentBody: I'm surprised no one has brought up the fact that sexting and other digital flirting isn't just for single people and cheaters. LOTS of people in relationships do this with their partner to keep things spicy. This may be one reason why rates are lower among teens. The statistics in this article don't say how many people are sending/receiving from people other than their partners. I'm just saying... I'm not too disturbed or surprised by the figures. And please, can we stop pointing at Facebook as the root of all social ills?

My comments about sprouting referred to sprouting seeds at home--and using a reliable source of organic seeds. My personal experience has been with one company, The Sprout People, who have been in business for many years.

After reading many of the negative comments that followed I contacted the company & asked them to weigh in.

I heard from them immediately--and here's what they had to say about home sprouting with THEIR TESTED CERTIFIED SEEDS. Everyone can decide for themselves, but I'm going to continue to sprout at home--which are the ONLY sprouts I eat.

"In light of the recent pathogenic outbreak in Germany, that has been Inked to Mung Bean sprouts, we want to advise our customers that the safest food is that which you prepare in your own home.

As long as your Sprouter is clean, your hands are clean and you are using a clean water source such as tap water, you can be assured of the highest level of safety.

Some people may wish to take THE added precaution of adding to the soak water one quarter cup of white vinegar per quart of water or a few drops of Grapefruit Seed Extract (http://sproutpeople.org/supply/odds/gse.html). Either of these two sanitizers can be added to the soak water and will clean the seed's outer coat.

We want to remind you that buying seed from an organic source also increases your safety, since organic seeds are required to be handled in a much safer way than conventionally grown seed.

None of the tests conducted on the German bean sprouts showed contamination. However, after erroneously accusing Spanish cucumbers, the German authorities focused their attention on Mung Bean sprouts.

As is the case with epidemiological analysis, even if the lab tests don't prove conclusive, circumstantial evidence is used to determine the answer.

In this case, as in too many that have preceded it, sprouts were blamed, based solely on information collected about where and what people ate, regardless of the tests coming back clean. They will probably never know for certain what food was involved.

All of our seeds have been tested and are free of pathogenic bacteria. We eat sprouts grown from the same seeds we sell to you, as we always have and as our children and pets always have. We continue to eat them without fear, and always will.

Be well and happy.

Gil and Lori
Sproutpeople

I haven't read all of the comments, but I'm a recipient of a heart/double lung transplant. The Team really made and still makes it so much easier for me. My surgery was over 8 years ago, and even with doctors & nurses & social workers changing, everyone stays aware of my current needs & physical conditions.
Lungs are hard to transplant, and their fragility means that they can't wait around very long before they're transplanted. They're always exposed to the outside world, unlike kidneys, livers, even hearts. The hospital called me c. 3 pm, but the surgery didn't start until midnight. Lasted 3 + hours.
I truly honor my surgeon & all the team members.

As someone who was suicidal as a 12-year-old, and who never got any psychological assistance (even though my whole family knew I had tried multiple times), I have never really shaken depression, but I also know there are other alternatives to taking leave of this world besides actually ending my life. There are more creative ways to kill yourself than the final way. Don't be in such a rush to end it.

And no, there is still a huge stigma attached to even discussing suicidal feelings. I'm in my 40's now and I can't even bring up the period when I was 12 without my parents getting outraged and acting like I am bringing up something shameful.

One other comment - to the people here who feel they are not supposed to be here.  I know the feeling.  But you are here.  You slipped through the velvet rope barrier.  Therefore, you have a unique perspective on life.  You have a special view of the proceedings.  Write it down or find some other way to express it.  Your perspective should be recorded.  Give yourself time to do that.

I lost my father a few weeks ago. I wanted to seek grief counseling and also seek help for the symptoms of depression that have resurfaced. However, I couldn't afford the hourly sessions for therapy and decided to join a gym instead. I swim four days a week, try to curb processed food, and keep friends and family close. Despite all these efforts, it's hard to shake off this feeling of wanting the earth to open up and swallow you whole.

Sometimes, despite all efforts to move on, I can't help but think it might be easier to seek out this hole. Yet, I am afraid. I have many goals I still want to accomplish. I have a network of friends and family that care for me deeply. I can't imagine hurting them this way, but there are many times I just want to give up.

To post #11 and #21, I feel the same way too, but I don't know what this says about me right now. Will this pass? I have no choice but to keep moving forward, but it is so hard.
That would be the special one. Just biding his time in Madrid....

As a cognitive behavioral therapist, I'm usually quite directive and active in session and engaged with my patients. There are times, though, with particular patients when I have become very bored, and find it difficult to stifle yawns. Usually, there is something diagnostically valuable in my boredom reaction; the patient is often relating to the content of the discussion in an emotionally detached way, or in some other way using self-protective avoidance. (I'm speaking in generalizations, of course.) I take this as a cue toward constructive action, and do something different, or even, in a gentle way, query the detachment and boredom, or the patient's present feeling or thinking, or change the perspective on the content.
How much sleep I've gotten may be a factor, but the urge to yawn is an important sign of what is going on in the session.

Are you serious??? No one is making you read the pet articles. As a pet owner, I am far from insulted - I enjoy these articles and find them informative. And as a volunteer with an organization that provides service dogs to the disabled, I know how much dogs can improve a person's health and well-being.

Also - nowhere is it written that one can either have a pet OR help the less fortunate. Believe it or not, some of us do both.

Now I think I'll go pet my dog to lower my blood pressure.

Enough with the dog articles in the health section! I'm a human. And, frankly, this elevation of the canine in America is short-sighted and sad. Why not feed a starving human instead of breeding countless canines and then lavishing them with organic food, etc. I know. I know. I'm heartless, cold, uncaring. Whetever. Start a pet column if you want, but please don't keep insulting your readers every time we click on the health section and we find ourselves limped in with the canines...again.
A therapist I saw years ago not only yawned but fell asleep twice and blamed it on me! Needless to say, I sought treatment elsewhere.

NEW BOOK , REAL HELP: Dr. Norman Rosenthal, the NIMH psychiatrist who informed the world about seasonal affective disorder (SAD) has a new book out now, coming on the NYT Bestseller list this weekend, about Transcendental Meditation and depression.  Based on his own personal experience, clinical experience, and extensive research, Dr. Rosenthal thinks that TM is even more important for the treatment and relief of depression than light therapy for SAD has been.  The book is "Transcendence: Healing and Transformation through Transcendental Meditation" by Normon Rosenthal.  One example of who it has worked for:  Howard Stern's mother's very serious, suicidal depression was lifted by TM-Howard tells about it on youtube - he credits TM for saving his mother's life.
Thanks for the insightful article.   Glad to have folks like you in the medical profession.

The idea that doctors need to be present 5 days a week is archaic.  As a cardiologist,  no one thought twice about my "unavailability" when I was scrubbed in the cardiac cath lab all day long--no one seemed to mind when my nurse and partners covered my patients for me.  Now that I am working 3 days a week, why am I any less a "good physician" when my partners cover me while I am with my children or friends instead of in the cath lab?  My spouse, who is a surgical oncologist, also works 3 days a week.  Does it matter if she is in the OR or at a school function when she is unavailable to take a phone call?  Not only to our children suffer when we overwork, physicians and patients suffer as well.

It is difficult to understand and believe Congress enacted a law requiring a government official to lie and to ignore science and medical studies. This renders the Office unreliable and a fraud. Though 68 - 84 % of this nation, depending on the poll, wants to legalize the medicinal use of cannabis, and science and medical studies have proven the therapeutic benefits and medicinal value of cannabis, we have been forced to live with outdated draconian laws. It is time to change this.

Part of the problem in making any changes to the drug policy of this nation is :

According to Title VII Office of National Drug Control Policy Reauthorization Act of 1998 :
Responsibilities: The Director "Drug Czar"
(12) shall ensure that no Federal funds appropriated to the Office of National Drug Control Policy shall be expended for any study or contract relating to the legalization (for a medical use or any other use) of a substance listed in schedule I of section 202 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 812) and take such actions as necessary to oppose any attempt to legalize the use of a substance (in any form) that--
(A) is listed in schedule I of section 202 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 812); and
(B) has not been approved for use for medical purposes by the Food and Drug Administration;

On April 2, 2003, Congressman Ron Paul wrote a letter to the United States General Accounting Office (GAO) asking for an investigation into ONDCP lobbying activities and their dissemination of "misleading information" (a polite euphemism for "lying").

The GAO responded :
"Finally, apart from considerations of whether any particular law has been violated, you have asked whether the Deputy Director's letter disseminated misleading information in connection with statements relating to the debate over legalization of marijuana. [...]
ONDCP is specifically charged with the responsibility for "taking such actions as necessary to oppose any attempt to legalize the use of certain controlled substances such as marijuana" - a responsibility which logically could include the making of advocacy statements in opposition to legalization efforts. The Deputy Director's statements about marijuana are thus within the statutory role assigned to ONDCP. Given this role, we do not see a need to examine the accuracy of the Deputy Director's individual statements in detail."

By law, the drug czar must oppose any attempt to legalize the use (in any form). Despite the science, medical studies and evidence of medical cannabis safety and effectiveness, despite the fact that the federal government supplies it to patients, despite the fact the Department of Health and Human Services holds patents on cannabinoids for the therapeutic benefits, US Patent 663057 titled "Cannabinoids as antioxidants and neuroprotectants" which is assigned to The United States of America, as represented by the Department of Health and Human Services) the drug czar is required by law to lie about it. Again, this renders the Office unreliable and a fraud.

While this is all a very complex subject with many twists and turns that I will leave to others, if we all lived in a culture and society that allowed, permitted and supported, fun, joy and excitement in all of its many subtle colors vs. crushing and shaming it out of all of us very early in life, this would be far less of a problem and scourge.  One stark reality check might be the addiction numbers in Russia now for just alcoholism and vodka alone.  It's scary spooky as well as understandable in its tragic, joyless and hopeless context just as meth addiction is in rural America.

One thing is for sure: we now know  that President Obama is no Franklin Roosevelt or Harry Truman.  Too bad for all the regular citizens of this country. Those two Presidents took on the Wall Street insiders and bankers. They stood up for working class citizens against the Republicans and their banking interest supporters. Just one example: President Roosevelt put in place programs that actually worked to save homes and farms from foreclosure including my grandfather's house on the Southside of Chicago.  Our family will never forget that. And millions of families who have now lost their homes to foreclosure will never forget that President Obama did little or nothing to help them.  If Roosevelt could find a way to do it, why can't Obama? Because the banks opposed it and still oppose it, the very same banks which precipitated the financial collapse, the very same banks whose financial support Obama now seems to think he needs to get reelected. Finally, please don't tell me Obama needed to restore the banks to financial health, for God's sake. His highest priority should have been to save the homeowners. But for him it's the banks, the banks, the banks.

Pay up "FAT CATS"! Obama believes he will be making more financial regulations for four more years!

The F.B.I general counsel, Valerie E. Caproni, has ignored the power given to the President's Foreign Intelligence Board (PFIAB) and their subcommittee; The Intelligence Oversight Board (IOB). Presidential Executive Order #12863 was first signed by President Ford in 1975. This Presidential Order established an independent oversight committee to monitor and report directly to the President if the intelligence community breaks any laws or does not adhere to Presidential Orders or Directives.
Presidential Executive Order 12863 has been modified by Presidents following his term. For example, President Clinton modified EO #12863 in 1993. Then in 2005, President Bush, amended Executive Order #12863 and the number changed from Executive Order #12683 to Executive Order #13376. However, in 2008, President Bush again amended the Executive Order #13376 and renamed it for a second time to President Executive Order #13462.
In conclusion, President Bush Executive Order #13462 of Feb. 29, 2008 re-establishing the Presidents Intelligence Advisory Board and Intelligence Oversight Board allows the IOB to investigate the F.B.I, C.I.A., N.S.A. and others insuring that our United States Constitution is being followed. In the United States Archives, www.archives.gov, Volume 73, No. 43, March 4, 2008 is where the Presidential Executive Order #13462 amended by President Bush is stored. Under the official section of the IOB powers, I quote the Executive order, "(b) inform the President of Intelligence activities that the IOB believes:
(i)(A) may be unlawful or contrary to Executive Order or Presidential Directive;"
The F.B.I. by enacting and giving F.B.I. agents complete authority to do what ever they want clearly violates "Presidential Executive Order #13462 signed into law by President Bush" and that violation is punishable by law. The F.B.I. has directly disobeyed direct orders enacted by the President. By doing so, the F.B.I. falls underneath the jurisdiction of the Intelligence Oversight Board for investigation of violating laws including American Civil Rights.
Semper Fidelis
I would like to cite that my facts were obtained from the United States National Archives. Their website is www.archives.gov.

Wow, a lot of people are mad at rating agencies. For the most part, they only simplify complex situations into alphanumeric ratings (A - aweseome, B - good, C - not so good...). The new rating reflects that Greece is likely to default. That the rating agency made a label for that situation doesn't change the fact of a likely default. And, that's what bond holders care about.

Don't make promises you can't keep. However good your intentions may be don't offer help or promise a visit if there is any chance you will not be following through.

I also have some advice for those who are sick. Remember that this is not just happening to you. It is also happening to everyone who loves and cares for you. As unfair as it may seem when you are lying in bed wracked in pain you do still have some responsibility to them. Having been on both sides of the bedpan I can honestly say that in some ways being the one who is sick is easier than being the one who has to helplessly sit and watch.

I was pretty shocked by how I was shunned.  After my surgery and treatment (kidney cancer), I had gone "home" for a much needed respite. One of my closest friends called me with the news that a neighbor of ours had just died of cancer. When I asked why she would make a point of telling me this, she responded tartly, "I thought you, of all people would want to know!" We haven't spoken since.
